長阿含經

The Medium Discourses

(七) 世間福經

7. Worldly Merit

我聞如是：一時，佛遊拘舍彌，在瞿沙羅園。

1. I have heard thus: One time, the Buddha traveled to Kauśāmbī and stayed at Gosira Park.1

  1. Gosira Park. This is the Sanskrit equivalent of Gositarama in Pali sources.

爾時，尊者摩訶周那則於晡時從宴坐起，往詣佛所，到已作禮，却坐一面，白曰：「世尊！可得施設世間福耶？」

2. At the time, the Venerable Mahācunda rose from his seat of repose late in the afternoon and went to visit the Buddha. When he arrived, he bowed and withdrew to sit at one side. He said, “Bhagavān, would it be possible to define worldly merit?”

世尊告曰：「可得。周那！有七世間福，得大福祐，得大果報，得大名譽，得大功德。云何為七？周那！有信族姓男、族姓女，施比丘眾房舍、堂閣。周那！是謂第一世間之福，得大福祐，得大果報，得大名譽，得大功德。

3. The Bhagavān told him, “It’s possible, Cunda. There are seven worldly merits that obtain great fortune, great rewards, great renown, and great virtue. What are the seven? Cunda, there are the faithful clansmen and clanswomen who give monasteries and meeting halls to the assembly of monks. This, Cunda, is the first worldly merit that obtains great fortune, great rewards, great renown, and great virtue.

「復次，周那！有信族姓男、族姓女，於房舍中施與床座、氍[毯-炎+數]、[1]𣯾𣰆、[2]氈褥、臥具。周那！是謂第二世間之福，得大福祐，得大果報，得大名譽，得大功德。

4. “Furthermore, Cunda, there are the faithful clansmen and clanswomen who go into monasteries and give them seats, carpets, blankets, mattresses, and bedding supplies.2 This, Cunda, is the second worldly merit that obtains great fortune, great rewards, great renown, and great virtue.

  1. carpets, blankets, mattresses. The Chinese for these terms uses obscure classical expressions that were used for different things over the ages. I’ve translated them generally, but the items in the original text may have been more specific than this.

「復次，周那！有信族姓男、族姓女，於房舍中施與一切新淨妙衣。周那！是謂第三世間之福，得大福祐，得大果報，得大名譽，得大功德。

5. “Furthermore, Cunda, there are the faithful clansmen and clanswomen who go into monasteries and give everyone new, clean, and marvelous clothing. This, Cunda, is the third worldly merit that obtains great fortune, great rewards, great renown, and great virtue.

「復次，周那！有信族姓男、族姓女，於房舍中常施於眾朝粥、中食，又以園民供給使令，若風雨寒雪，躬往園所，增施供養。諸比丘眾食已，不患風雨寒雪[3]沽漬衣服，晝夜安樂禪寂思惟。周那！是謂第七世間之福，得大福祐，得大果報，得大名譽，得大功德。

6. “Furthermore, Cunda, there are the faithful clansmen and clanswomen who go into monasteries and give the community the morning rice gruel and midday meals. They also tell their servants to serve the monastery, and they give additional offerings to the monastery when there are rain and snow storms, so the assembly of monks aren’t troubled after eating about the bad weather making their robes wet. Day and night, they meditate and contemplate in comfort instead. This, Cunda, is the seventh worldly merit that obtains great fortune, great rewards, great renown, and great virtue.

「周那！信族姓男、族姓女已得此七世間福者，若去若來，若立若坐，若眠若覺，若晝若夜，其福常生，轉增轉廣。

7. “Cunda, for faithful clansmen and clanswomen who have obtained these seven worldly merits, their merits will always arise, becoming greater and broader whether its in the past or future, while standing or sitting, or whether asleep, awake, day, or night.

周那！譬如恒伽水，從源流出，入于大海，於其中間轉深轉廣。周那！如是信族姓男、族姓女已得此七世間福者，若去若來，若立若坐，若眠若覺，若晝若夜，其福常生，轉增轉廣。」

8. “Cunda, it’s like the Gaṅgā River, which flows from it’s source to the ocean. It becomes deeper and wider as it goes. Thus, Cunda, are faithful clansmen and clanswomen who have obtained these seven worldly merits. Their merits will always arise, becoming greater and broader whether its in the past or future, while standing or sitting, or whether asleep, awake, day, or night.”

於是，尊者摩訶周那即從[4]坐起，偏袒右肩，右膝著地，長跪叉手白曰：「世尊！可得施設出世間福耶？」

9. Venerable Mahācunda then rose from his seat, adjusted his robes from his right shoulder, knelt on his right knee, and saluted with his palms together. He said, “Bhagavān, would it be possible to define the merits that transcend the world?”

世尊告曰：「可得。周那！更有七福出於世間，得大福祐，得大果報，得大名譽，得大功德。云何為七？周那！有信族姓男、族姓女，聞如來、如來弟子遊於某處，聞已歡喜，極懷踊躍。周那！是謂第一出世間福，得大福祐，得大果報，得大名譽，得大功德。

10. The Bhagavān addressed him, “It’s possible to define the merits that transcend the world. There are another seven merits that transcend the world and obtain great fortune, great rewards, great renown, and great virtue. What are the seven? Cunda, there are the faithful clansmen and clanswomen who hear that the Tathāgata or one of his disciples have traveled to a certain place, and they rejoice upon hearing about it, celebrating in their hearts. Cunda, this is the first merit that transcends the world and obtains great fortune, great rewards, great renown, and great virtue.

「復次，周那！有信族姓男、族姓女，聞如來、如來弟子欲從彼至此，聞已歡喜，極懷踊躍。周那！是謂第二出世間福，得大福祐，得大果報，得大名譽，得大功德。

11. “Furthermore, Cunda, there are the faithful clansmen and clanswomen who hear that the Tathāgata or one of his disciples are about to come from that place to their own, and they rejoice upon hearing about it, celebrating in their hearts. Cunda, this is the second merit that transcends the world and obtains great fortune, great rewards, great renown, and great virtue.

「復次，周那！有信族姓男、族姓女，聞如來、如來弟子已從彼至此，聞已歡喜，極懷踊躍，以清淨心躬往奉見，禮敬供養，既供養已，受三自歸於佛、法[5]及比丘眾，而受禁戒。周那！是謂第七出世間福，得大福祐，得大果報，得大名譽，得大功德。

12. “Furthermore, Cunda, there are the faithful clansmen and clanswomen who hear that the Tathāgata or one of his disciples have arrived from there, and they rejoice upon hearing it, celebrating in their hearts. They go personally to see them with a pure heart, and they pay their respects and make offerings. Once they had made offerings, they thrice take refuge in the Buddha, teaching, and community of monks, and they accept the precepts. This, Cunda is the seventh merit that transcends the world and obtains great fortune, great rewards, great renown, and great virtue.

「周那！[6]信族姓男、族姓女若得此七世間之福及更有七出世間福者，其福不可數，有爾所福，爾所福果，爾所福報，唯不可限、不可量、不可[7]得大福之數。

13. “Cunda, if a faithful clansmen and clanswoman were to attain these seven worldly merits and these other seven merits that transcend the world, their merits would be incalculable. Possessing such merits, the results of such merits, and the rewards of such merits, they simply cannot be delimited, cannot be measured, and the number of those great merits cannot be found.

周那！譬如從閻浮洲有五河流：一曰恒伽，二曰搖尤那，三曰舍勞浮，四曰阿夷羅婆提，五曰摩企，流入大海，於其中間水不可數，有爾所[8]升斛，唯不可限，不可量、不可得大水之數。

14. “Cunda, it’s like the five rivers that are in Jambudvīpa: 1. The Gaṅgā, 2. Yamunā, 3. Sarabhu, 4. Ajiravatī, and 5. Mahī. They flow down into the ocean, and their water is incalculable. The volume that it possesses simply cannot be delimited, cannot be measured, and the amount of water cannot be found.

周那！如是信族姓男、族姓女若得此七世間之福及更有七出世間福者，[9]其福不可數，有爾所福，爾所福果，爾所福報，唯不可限、不可量、不可得大福之數。」'

15. “Cunda, if such a faithful clansman or clanswoman attains these seven worldly merits and those other seven merits that transcend the world, their merits would be incalculable. Possessing such merits, the results of such merits, and the rewards of such merits, they simply cannot be delimited, cannot be measured, and the number of those great merits cannot be found.”

爾時，世尊而說頌曰：

16. At that time, the Bhagavān spoke in verse:

「恒伽之河，　　清淨易[10]渡， 　海多珍寶，　　眾水中王。

  1. “The Gaṅgā River
    Is clean and easy to cross;
    The ocean with many treasures
    Is the king of myriad rivers.

　猶若河水，　　世人敬奉， 　諸川所歸，　　引入大海。

  1. Like a river’s flow,
    A worldly person bows low;
    That’s where streams return
    As they go forth into the ocean.

　如是人者，　　施衣飲食， 　床㯓茵褥，　　及諸坐具。

  1. Such a person
    Gives clothes, food, and drink;
    Beds, sofas, mats,
    And things upon which to sit.

　無量福報，　　將至妙處， 　猶若河水，　　引入大海。」

  1. Measureless rewards of merit
    Lead him to a marvelous place;
    He’s like the river’s flow
    Going forth into the ocean.”

佛說如是。尊者摩訶周那及諸比丘，聞佛所說，歡喜奉行。

17. The Buddha spoke thus. The Venerable Mahācunda and the monks who heard what the Buddha had taught rejoiced and handed it down.

Translator: Charles Patton
